claim: Israel's official X account made a post on Feb. 4, 2024, about humanitarian aid it said it had provided to Gaza that included a video clip showing an unrelated Ukrainian refugee camp in Moldova.
content:
The protracted, often bloody Israeli-Palestinian conflict exploded into a hot war on Oct. 7, 2023, when the militant Palestinian group Hamas launched a deadly attack on Israel and Israel retaliated by bombarding the Gaza Strip. More than 20,000 people, the vast majority of them Palestinians, were reportedly killed during the first two months of the war alone. The violence is driven by mutual hostilities and territorial ambitions dating back more than a century. The internet has become an unofficial front in that war and is rife with misinformation, which Snopes is dedicated to countering with facts and context. You can help. Read the latest fact checks. Submit questionable claims. Become a Snopes Member to support our work. We welcome your participation and feedback.
On Feb. 4, 2024, the @Israel account on X — Israel's official presence on the social media platform — posted a 30-second video listing the humanitarian aid it claimed it had provided for the people of Gaza in the months since the Israel-Hamas war began.
A claim emerged the following week that footage included in the video depicted an unrelated Ukrainian refugee camp, not Gaza. We rate this claim as "True."
Above the video in the post on X, the caption included a list that claimed Israel had provided aid to Gazans in the form of 11,000 trucks, 140,000 tons of food, 1,000 water trucks, 17,000 tons of medical supplies and 23,000 tons of tents and shelter equipment.
"Israel will continue to facilitate the transfer of life-saving humanitarian aid to Gaza," the post continued. "Our war is with Hamas, not with the people of Gaza." The post ended with the hashtag #FreeGazaFromHamas.
During the brief video, a narrator's voice-over mentioned the same statistics regarding aid Israel said it had provided to Gaza.
"Israel does not limit the amount of humanitarian aid that can enter Gaza," the narrator began. "Since Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, over 11,000 trucks of humanitarian aid have entered Gaza, carrying over 140,000 tons of food, over 1,000 water trucks, almost 17,000 tons of medical supplies and approximately 23,000 tons of tents and shelter equipment. We are at war with Hamas, not the people of Gaza."
Eight days later, on Feb. 12, @Israel's post and video from @Israel were no longer available and appeared to have been deleted. Shortly before the post disappeared, BBC Verify journalist Shayan Sardarizadeh reported via X, "The official state of Israel account has posted this video, saying it is facilitating aid into Gaza. A short clip at the end of the video, claiming to show tents and shelter equipment for Gazans, was actually filmed in March 2022, showing tents in Moldova for Ukrainian refugees."
The official state of Israel account has posted this video, saying it is facilitating aid into Gaza.
A short clip at the end of the video, claiming to show tents and shelter equipment for Gazans, was actually filmed in March 2022, showing tents in Moldova for Ukrainian refugees. pic.twitter.com/gKW2O1VdPF
— Shayan Sardarizadeh (@Shayan86) February 12, 2024

The same brief video clip that appeared at the end of the video posted by @Israel to represent "approximately 23,000 tons of tents and shelter equipment" was available on the Getty Images website, where it was dated as having been recorded on March 21, 2022. It was originally described as follows: "Land arranged on the territory of Moldova with tents near the border of Ukraine for refugees coming from the war in Ukraine."
This video clip had nothing to do with Israel or Gaza.
As of this writing, the same video that had been posted and removed from the @Israel account on X was available from official social media accounts for the Embassy of Israel in the U.S., including on Facebook, X, Instagram and TikTok.
Snopes reached out to Israel's Ministry of Foreign Affairs to ask about the removed post and will update this story if a response is received.

original_rationales.main_rationale: A claim emerged the following week that footage included in the video depicted an unrelated Ukrainian refugee camp, not Gaza. We rate this claim as "True."
original_rationales.additional_rationale3: This video clip had nothing to do with Israel or Gaza.

summary_rationales.synthesized_rationale: The 'True' rating for the claim that Israel's official account posted a video showing a Ukrainian refugee camp instead of aid to Gaza is supported by evidence in the text confirming the misrepresentation, including the video's actual origin and the subsequent deletion of the post. The rating is justified by the discrepancy between the claimed aid to Gaza and the actual footage shown in the video.

detailed_reasons.reason1: The video posted by Israel's official account claiming to depict aid for Gaza was proven to show a Ukrainian refugee camp in Moldova instead, as evidenced by a journalist's report. This discrepancy between the claimed content and the actual content supports the 'True' rating.
detailed_reasons.reason2: The video clip shown in the post, indicating tents and shelter equipment for Gazans, was identified as being from Moldova for Ukrainian refugees with a specific date attached, further affirming the misrepresentation of the content. This specific evidence aligns with the 'True' rating.
detailed_reasons.reason3: The deletion of the post by @Israel's account after the misinformation was exposed indicates acknowledgment of the error or attempt to rectify the situation. This action is consistent with a 'True' rating as it reflects a recognition of the misleading nature of the video.
detailed_reasons.reason4: The availability of the same video clip on other official social media accounts of the Embassy of Israel in the U.S. confirms its origin and the spread of misleading information across various platforms, reinforcing the validity of the 'True' rating.

evidence1: The protracted, often bloody Israeli-Palestinian conflict exploded into a hot war on Oct. 7, 2023, when the militant Palestinian group Hamas launched a deadly attack on Israel and Israel retaliated by bombarding the Gaza Strip. More than 20,000 people, the vast majority of them Palestinians, were reportedly killed during the first two months of the war alone. The violence is driven by mutual hostilities and territorial ambitions dating back more than a century. relationship_with_evidence.main_rationale, evidence1: The evidence directly supports the main rationale that a claim emerged that the footage in the video depicted an unrelated Ukrainian refugee camp, not Gaza. The evidence explicitly states that a short clip at the end of the video showing tents and shelter equipment for Gazans was actually filmed in March 2022 in Moldova for Ukrainian refugees, aligning with the main rationale's assertion.

relationship_with_evidence.reason2, evidence1: The evidence directly supports reason2 presented in the Combined Claim and Rationale. The article confirms that the video clip shown in the post, depicting tents and shelter equipment for Gazans, was actually from Moldova for Ukrainian refugees, with a specific date attached. This evidence aligns with the 'True' rating and the reason provided, reinforcing the misrepresentation of content by Israel's official account.

relationship_with_evidence.main_rationale,evidence2: The evidence directly supports the main rationale which states that the claim about humanitarian aid provided to Gaza including a video clip showing an unrelated Ukrainian refugee camp in Moldova is true. The evidence mentions that the video posted by Israel's official account was actually a clip from March 2022 showing tents in Moldova for Ukrainian refugees, not Gaza, thereby confirming the main rationale's assertion that the footage was indeed unrelated to Gaza.

relationship_with_evidence.reason2, evidence2: The evidence directly supports reason2 from the combined claim and rationale. The evidence mentioned in the tweet by Shayan Sardarizadeh confirms that the video clip, claimed to show aid for Gaza, actually displayed tents in Moldova for Ukrainian refugees. This clear discrepancy aligns with reason2, which states the misrepresentation of the content by Israel's official account, supporting the 'True' rating.
